--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, didoss@c... wrote:
> My problem is usually al=
ong the lines of: I make changes to classA, 
> which is used in classB, whi=
ch is used in classC, which is tested by
> testC.  So, I have modified test=
A, which directly tests classA, but 
> don't realize that I have broken som=
ething in testC.  My solution is
> that we run nightlybuilds, and I check t=
he errors/failures the next 
> morning to see if my code changes could have=
 caused any of them.
> 
> It would be nice to be a little more proactive, t=
hough,...being able
> to (easily) find all the tests that are ultimately af=
fected by my 
> code change (iterating through the workspace references unt=
il I 
> terminate at all classes that start with "Test", or that are in my =

> test branch).  I know that I can do this manually through Eclipse, 
> bu=
t it is not fun - and therefore doesn't get done.

How long does it take to=
 run all your tests? That would be the obvious
first answer, I'd suggest.

=
Also, if you try to make your tests only test a single unit, that
helps a l=
ot - and using mock objects helps there (I use EasyMock
myself). It certain=
ly doesn't solve the problem 100%, but it's a good
start.

Jon
